name: Jeff Duncan
content:
Welcome home CPL McCollum.

Today we laid CPL William James McCollum to rest at Dolly Cooper Cemetery in Anderson, SC, on what would have been his 90th birthday. It was a beautiful ceremony, attended by folks throughout our community.

CPL McCollum was a member of Company D, 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 7th Infantry Division, 31st Regimental Combat Team. He was reported missing in action December 2nd, 1950, in the vicinity of the Chosin Reservoir, North Korea, when enemy forces attacked his unit. It was not until December 31st, 1953, that he was declared dead, with his family receiving an Army telegram. The location of his body was unknown, until the June 2018 summit between President Donald J. Trump and North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong-un during which North Korea turned over 55 sets of remains of American service members killed during the Korean War.

All gave some; some gave all.

name: Doug LaMalfa
content: Juneteenth, June 19, 1865, is our recognition of the emancipation of the last pocket of slaves to learn they were free after the Civil War finally ended. It took two years for Union Soldiers to have a large enough force in Texas to enforce the Emancipation Proclamation that Lincoln signed September 22, 1862 and went into effect January 1, 1863. It was only after the surrender of General Lee in April of 1865 that significant troops were available to be dispatched to ensure Lincoln‚Äôs proclamation was in effect. Hundreds of thousands of men, women and children of all races died to bring an end to the sin that was slavery. Juneteenth symbolizes that final trek, that the word of freedom had been delivered, that the promise of Emancipation had reached its glorious fulfillment.
text: juneteenth june recognition emancipation last pocket slaves learn free civil war finally ended took two years union soldiers large enough force texas enforce emancipation proclamation lincoln signed september went effect january surrender general lee april significant troops available dispatched ensure lincolns proclamation effect hundreds thousands men women children races died bring end sin slavery juneteenth symbolizes final trek word freedom delivered promise emancipation reached glorious fulfillment

name: Jeff Duncan
content:
Following the June 2018 summit between President Donald J. Trump and North Korean Supreme Leader Kim Jong-un, North Korea turned over 55 sets of remains of American service members killed during the Korean War. The remains arrived at Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam, Hawaii, on August 1st, 2018, and were subsequently accessioned into the DPAA laboratory for identification. Using laboratory analysis and circumstantial evidence, DPAA analysts identified CPL McCollum from among these remains.

CPL McCollum was a member of Company D, 1st Battalion, 32nd Infantry Regiment, 7th Infantry Division, 31st Regimental Combat Team. He was reported missing in action December 2nd, 1950, in the vicinity of the Chosin Reservoir, North Korea, when enemy forces attacked his unit. It was not until December 31st, 1953, that he was declared dead, with his family receiving an Army telegram. The location of his body, however, was unknown. As decades passed, Corporal McCollum‚Äôs family still hoped his remains would be returned home.

Without the sacrifice of heroes like CPL McCollum, freedom and liberty never would have been possible on the Korean peninsula. He is a true American hero, and we welcome him home to rest in peace.

CPL McCollum will be laid to rest at Dolly Cooper Cemetery in Anderson, SC, at 1 pm on Saturday, June 19th, his 90th birthday. He will also be lying in state from 8:30 am-5 pm on Friday, June 18th.

"Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one‚Äôs life for one‚Äôs friends." - John 15:13

WYFF4.COM
Soldier's homecoming: Remains of Korean War veteran finally return to Upstate
text: following june summit president donald j trump north korean supreme leader kim jongun north korea turned sets remains american service members killed korean war remains arrived joint base pearl harborhickam hawaii august 1st subsequently accessioned dpaa laboratory identification using laboratory analysis circumstantial evidence dpaa analysts identified cpl mccollum among remainscpl mccollum member company 1st battalion 32nd infantry regiment 7th infantry division 31st regimental combat team reported missing action december 2nd vicinity chosin reservoir north korea enemy forces attacked unit december 31st declared dead family receiving army telegram location body however unknown decades passed corporal mccollums family still hoped remains would returned homewithout sacrifice heroes like cpl mccollum freedom liberty never would possible korean peninsula true american hero welcome home rest peacecpl mccollum laid rest dolly cooper cemetery anderson sc pm saturday june 19th 90th birthday also lying state am5 pm friday june 18thgreater love one lay ones life ones friends john 1513wyff4comsoldiers homecoming remains korean war veteran finally return upstate

name: Derek Kilmer
content: I enjoyed joining a great crowd in Bremerton this afternoon to celebrate #Juneteenth! I‚Äôm proud to have taken an important vote this week - to make Juneteenth a national holiday. It‚Äôs important to consecrate this day as a day of remembrance of our nation‚Äôs original sin. It‚Äôs important to commemorate this day as celebration of emancipation. It‚Äôs important to embrace this day as a day of education and of honoring Black history. And it is important to recognize that first step toward freedom for the ancestors of our Black brothers and sisters that day 156 years ago in Texas. We should indeed celebrate those steps, but also recognize that we have more steps to take to create a more just society!

name: Bill Johnson
content:
‚ÄúThere shall be neither slavery nor involuntary servitude in the said territory.‚Äù

With that simple sentence in the Northwest Ordinance of 1787, slavery was outlawed in a territory the size of the original 13 colonies. A year later, that territory would be settled permanently by the pioneers of the Ohio Company at Marietta, Ohio. Then, in 1862, President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation. But, word didn‚Äôt travel quite as quickly then as it does today. On June 19, 1865, two-and-a-half months after the Confederacy surrendered, an announcement by a Union Army general proclaimed freedom from slavery in Texas ‚Äì the last enslaved people were freed and the scourge of slavery was ended.

Today we reflect on the fundamental truth that our inalienable rights to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness that extend to all people, regardless of race, are not given to us by politicians or government; rather, they‚Äôre endowed to us by our Creator. This must be so, because if our rights were granted by government they could be taken by government.

America has made enormous progress on race and equality ‚Äî an undeniable truth, but a truth too often muted by media and politicians who benefit politically and financially from stoking division.

We are a nation of fundamentally good people, our institutions are democratic, and our history is proud but not perfect. And today, we recommit to being one nation, under God, with liberty and justice for all.

name: Salud O. Carbajal

I was proud to cast my vote to make Juneteenth a federal holiday, cementing this celebration of freedom for enslaved African Americans as an American tradition. This is long overdue and I am thankful for the advocacy of all those who have helped make this possible.

Local black leaders like Congressional Women of the Year Sojourner Kincaid Rolle and Courtney Hale have been relentless advocates for social justice in our community. Please join them in their celebrations of local black life by visiting naacpslocty.org and juneteenthsb.org.

name: Eric Swalwell
content:
I was deeply touched by the words of Karman Singh, whose brother, Taptejdeep Singh, was among the nine victims of last month‚Äôs mass shooting at the VTA yard in San Jose. He spoke a few minutes ago at an event in Union City in solidarity against gun violence, striving to honor Taptejdeep‚Äôs memory while he and his family grapple with the pain of his murder.

Taptejdeep Singh was a hero to his family and friends through his positivity and graciousness, his compassion and empathy. And he was a hero the day he died, trying to warn his co-workers away and keep them safe.

Each of the victims was a hero to someone.

Thoughts and prayers aren‚Äôt enough. Vigils and ceremonies aren‚Äôt enough. Let‚Äôs act to make sure we don‚Äôt lose more heroes.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
Juneteenth marks the day in 1865 when word of emancipation finally reached enslaved people in Texas ‚Äì providing these individuals with a new measure of freedom. Just as Americans learn the story of July 4, understanding and celebrating Juneteenth as a critical part of American history is vital. June 19 should be a national holiday ‚Äì I was proud to vote in support of the bill to officially designate it as such, which just passed the Senate this week.

As America continues to grapple with systemic racism, a holiday centered on the story of the delayed promise of freedom has perhaps never been so apt. Take some time today to learn about the history of Juneteenth, celebrate freedom, and recommit to the ongoing work of securing true freedom for all Americans, no matter the color of their skin or their origin.

LATIMES.COM
Hikes, food, music and more. Here are 25 Juneteenth events happening around L.A.

name: Adam B. Schiff
content:
Monday, June 21st at 8:30pm ET: Join me and representatives from Guns Down America, Giffords, and Survivors Empowered for a LIVE virtual discussion on why must hold the gun industry accountable and give victims and survivors of gun violence their day in court.

One of the most critical steps we can take to curb gun violence in America is repealing the law the NRA has called its ‚Äú#1 priority,‚Äù but you‚Äôve probably never heard of: the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act (PLCAA). This 2005 law provides the gun industry with an unprecedented immunity from liability that no other industry enjoys, and which has denied families their day in court. I introduced a bill to end this legal loophole and ensure the gun industry is held accountable when it acts with negligent disregard for public safety.

Register here: https://giffords-org.zoom.us/.../WN_7sRG8XIGQFS2oSy4Ai3__A
Questions? Leave them in the comments below üëá

name: Jackie Speier
content:
Earlier this week, I proudly joined my colleagues from both sides of the aisle in the House of Representatives to make Juneteenth, which has been celebrated for generations by families and communities throughout America, a federal holiday.

The formal commemoration of the end of slavery and the independence of African Americans is a critically important step in our country‚Äôs efforts to overcome its racist roots. It is not, however, a panacea for the systemic racism that grew from America‚Äôs shameful history of slavery and that continues to this day.

As we celebrate Juneteenth today, let us all take a moment to consider the importance of this milestone moment and recommit ourselves to the fight against inequity, oppression, and discrimination in order to form that more perfect union.

name: Scott Perry
content: I was honored to vote in favor of a bill this week to make Juneteenth a federal holiday. Juneteenth commemorates the day in 1865 when the last remaining enslaved people in Galveston, Texas finally learned of their freedom, established by the Emancipation Proclamation over two years before. Juneteenth not only recognizes the horrors and inequities of slavery and the triumph of emancipation, but it‚Äôs also an opportunity to celebrate the blessings of freedoms for all Americans. Within our American Freedom is the core of our goodness, humanity, and joy. Please enjoy this American holiday ‚Äì Happy Juneteenth. #Juneteenth #Freedom #GodBlessAmerica

name: Alan S. Lowenthal
content:
I was proud to vote this week to make Juneteenth a national holiday. I was also pleased that the vote was overwhelming and bipartisan.

The slaves of Galveston, Texas, had to wait more than two years after President Lincoln‚Äôs Emancipation Proclamation and two months after the end of the Civil War to receive word that they were now free. As President Obama said in one of his June 19th proclamations observing Juneteenth, ‚ÄúToday, we commemorate the anniversary of that delayed but welcome news.‚Äù

For 155 years, Juneteenth has been both a celebration of freedom and heritage and also a solemn reminder of the legacies of slavery and racism which scar our country. It is also a time to remember how far we as a nation have come, while focusing on how much more we have to do in the quest for equality for every American. Even more so this year, we should take this time to reflect on the injustice and inequalities that still confront Black Americans, and recommit ourselves to being part of the solution.

name: Debbie Wasserman Schultz
content:
Juneteenth is not only a joyous celebration of Black America‚Äôs freedom, history and triumphs, it is also an opportunity to reflect on just how far as a nation we still must travel to bring liberty and justice to all. This commemoration comes at a tenuous time in America, as it also marks one year since the largest civil rights marches in half a century following the murder of George Floyd. While one of the officers responsible for Floyd‚Äôs death has since been convicted, not nearly enough has been done to end systemic police brutality and reform the criminal justice system. That must include federal police reforms, but it must also involve dismantling the racism embedded within all American institutions. Equally important, we must acknowledge that we are facing an unprecedented attack on voting rights and take Federal action to stop it.

I‚Äôve proudly cosponsored several bills, including H.R. 1 and H.R. 4, to establish federal protections and prevent institutional voter disenfranchisement. In addition to cosponsoring and authoring police reform and voting rights legislation, I proudly cosponsored and voted to pass Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee‚Äôs bill to recognize Juneteenth as a federal holiday. I am proud that President Joe Biden swiftly made this our 12th federal holiday, to mark the immense toll slavery took, and still exacts on our nation. Only through learning and understanding can we achieve peace and equality for every American.

name: Doug LaMalfa
content: This week I spoke about the need to reform the Endangered Species Act (ESA). The ESA was signed into law by President Nixon in 1973 to protect vulnerable species, but now this law has been weaponized to prevent needed forest management, water storage and other infrastructure projects, and even agricultural plantings. We are in the middle of a drought here in California, but we are releasing water from our dams into the ocean because of the ESA. Farmers can‚Äôt get water, so crops aren‚Äôt being planted. This means you will not see California agricultural products on your store shelves‚Äîyou will have to settle for nothing or rely on expensive foreign imports. Forest thinning projects are being halted by lawsuits based on the ESA. While the necessary work is on hold pending a decision on a given lawsuit, wildfire comes through and wipes out the very habitats the litigants were trying to ‚Äúprotect.‚Äù How are megafires good for these species? We need reforms now before the ESA can be used to further harm rural Americans. Watch my full speech:

name: Anthony Brown
content:
The institution of slavery didn‚Äôt end when President Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, it wasn‚Äôt until 1865, when the news reached Galveston, Texas, that many enslaved persons finally gained their freedom.

Juneteenth recognizes this crucial moment for Black Freedom, a celebration of joy and the work ahead of us. As a nation, we‚Äôve made progress towards molding our founding ideals of freedom and equality to reach every American. However, many Black Americans continue to face the effects of systemic racism and policies rooted in oppression. We must commit to making real change and call for reform in criminal justice, healthcare, housing, and economic opportunity for those in our society facing barriers.

It‚Äôs important to take a moment today to celebrate how far we have come, while reflecting on the pain endured by so many. Let‚Äôs celebrate African American freedom, perseverance, and achievement in the United States, and remember that we must all take a stand and call for equality, equity, and justice.

name: Bill Johnson
content:
Happy Father‚Äôs Day! For me, today is a day to reflect on just how important the role of a father is in the lives of his children. Some of you may know, I was raised in a dysfunctional home. My father was an alcoholic, and he struggled with addiction his entire life. Consequently, he was not there for me as a young boy when I needed him. Perhaps you can relate to this in your own life. Fortunately, for me, many strong men ‚Äì both family and those I met in my military career ‚Äì stepped in to fill the void. God used them greatly to mold and mentor me along the path life took me‚Ä¶and I‚Äôm extremely grateful for that. So, today I want to encourage all you fathers out there.

Several Bible verses come to mind this morning, but they are not traditional Father‚Äôs Day passages. But throughout this past week, I‚Äôve been reminded of them often. I‚Äôve now come to see that they are very appropriate verses for today. They come from the book of Ephesians‚Ä¶the Apostle Paul is encouraging the believers in the church at Ephesus. Though not directed specifically to fathers, they apply to all people‚Ä¶and I can think of no better encouragement to fathers who desire so strongly to be a positive influence in the lives of their children.

Ephesians 1:17 - I keep asking that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the glorious Father, may give you the Spirit of wisdom and revelation, so that you may know him better.

Ephesians 4:1-2 - As a prisoner for the Lord, then, I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received. Be completely humble and gentle; be patient, bearing with one another in love.

It takes a great deal of patience, love, and humility to be an effective father‚Ä¶especially in today‚Äôs world with all the demands on a father‚Äôs time and the many challenges our children face. I believe strongly that it takes God‚Äôs direct intervention in the lives of fathers to help them navigate the challenges of parenthood. So, if you are a father today, these are my prayers for you. First, that God would send his Holy Spirit to give you wisdom and revelation so that you can know him better. Because only by knowing God better can we, as fathers, meet the challenges ahead with confidence and purpose. And second, that you would be gentle, patient, loving, and humble in your role as father to your children. You will make mistakes, but by living out these attributes, the love you have for your children will ultimately claim the day. God bless you and have a great Father‚Äôs Day.

name: Eric Swalwell
content: I enjoyed stopping by Hayward's glorious Juneteenth celebration today, and talking with many of the residents and elected officials there. Although it's great that Juneteenth is now a federal holiday, we have a lot of work to do to correct enduring inequalities and bring better health, safety, education, and job opportunities to our Black communities.

name: Ted Budd
content:
The current crisis on the southern border is completely out of control. Last month, U.S. Customs and Border Protection announced that over 180,000 illegal aliens were encountered at the southern border in May. This is a 674% increase from May 2020.

What is most outrageous about this situation is the Biden-Harris Administration‚Äôs policy change that no longer detains illegal aliens who are captured illegally crossing the border. Instead, they are processed, given a simple piece of paper requesting that they report to Immigration and Customs Enforcement at a later date, and then released into the U.S. mainland.

In reality, this new policy functionally opens our border and allows a free flow of illegal migrants into our country. This is particularly dangerous given the fact that drug cartels and trans-national criminal gangs are known to take advantage of our open border policies to traffic in deadly drugs and innocent human beings.

This is completely unacceptable. I will continue to stand up for proven methods that reduce illegal immigration that were in place during the Trump Administration: Constructing a border wall, reinstating the Migrant Protection Protocols, and deporting criminal illegal aliens. This approach has been proven to disincentivize illegal immigration and allow border patrol to regain operational control of the border.

name: Matt Cartwright
content:
As we celebrate #Juneteenth, let us all think about the enormity of what this day means for our country. I was so proud to cast my vote this week to make a national holiday of the day we finally cast off the shameful pall of slavery. I‚Äôm also proud that Pennsylvania was a thought center of the American abolitionist movement. If you visit the Library Company of Philadelphia, you can see and touch the original signed Act that abolished slavery in our Commonwealth, the first place in America to take that step. That was in 1780, even before the end of the Revolutionary War.

In the 8th Congressional District of Pennsylvania, we have a particular reason to smile at the Juneteenth holiday, since we actually served as a stop on the Underground Railroad. Waverly, PA, proudly lays claim to having assisted many fugitive slaves on their way to freedom, several of whom liked our area so much they chose to live out their lives there. Have a look at this short PBS clip about Waverly‚Äôs abolitionist history: https://www.pbs.org/video/the-underground-railroad-in-northeast-pa-uutpke/. So today, I hope you will join me in gratefulness that we will now be celebrating Juneteenth in perpetuity!
text: celebrate juneteenth let us think enormity day means country proud cast vote week make national holiday day finally cast shameful pall slavery im also proud pennsylvania thought center american abolitionist movement visit library company philadelphia see touch original signed act abolished slavery commonwealth first place america take step even end revolutionary warin 8th congressional district pennsylvania particular reason smile juneteenth holiday since actually served stop underground railroad waverly pa proudly lays claim assisted many fugitive slaves way freedom several liked area much chose live lives look short pbs clip waverlys abolitionist history today hope join gratefulness celebrating juneteenth perpetuity

name: Ed Perlmutter
content:
This morning, I had the great privilege and honor of recognizing Father Edward Flaherty, Jr. for his service to our country during WWII.

Father Flaherty, a 102-year-old Veteran, never received several medals for which he was entitled from his service in the U.S. Army from 1941 to 1945, including time in the Pacific theater of World War II. While serving in the Army, Father Flaherty was a Medical Technician with the 131st Engineer Regiment Medical Detachment, in which he played an essential role in treating his fellow soldiers‚Äô wounds and injuries while also assisting with evacuations for casualties.

Father Flaherty‚Äôs service helped to defend our nation‚Äôs democracy and ideals abroad at a crucial moment in world history. We are proud to have Father Flaherty call Colorado home for so many years, and forever indebted to him for his service to our community and sacrifice on behalf of our country. #TisAPrivilege

name: Barry Loudermilk
content: Juneteenth celebrates the end of slavery and commemorates June 19, 1865, when Union Gen. Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas, and brought the news that the Civil War had ended and the enslaved were free. The 13th Amendment was ratified a few months later, in December 1865, formally abolishing slavery in the U.S.

name: Robert J. Wittman
content:
On June 19, 1865, Union Army General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas to enforce the emancipation of slaves in Texas, freeing the remaining slaves in the South. This day became known as Juneteenth. This year, I was proud to vote in favor of the bipartisan effort to establish Juneteenth as a federal holiday.

Happy Juneteenth! As we celebrate, may we reflect and learn from our nation‚Äôs past, as we look forward to a more hopeful future.

name: Mike Bost
content: While President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on September 22, 1862, slavery in some parts of the confederacy did not end until over two years later. On June 19, 1865, Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas with the announcement that all slaves were free. This week, President Biden signed a new law designating Juneteenth a federal holiday, the first new federal holiday since MLK Jr. Day was established in 1983.

name: Bill Johnson
content: Steubenville native Edwin Stanton is this week‚Äôs famous Ohioan. He was a successful Ohio attorney who, in 1860, ran against Abraham Lincoln in the Republican Presidential Primary. Though he lost the primary, Lincoln had great respect for Stanton and recognized that he would fit well in his administration. At first, Stanton did not have great respect for Lincoln. In fact, it was rumored that Stanton once referred to Lincoln as a ‚Äúdamn fool‚Äù‚Ä¶to which Lincoln responded, ‚ÄúThen I dare say I must be one, for Stanton is generally right and he always says what he means.‚Äù Yet, after having worked with Lincoln for years and after watching Lincoln navigate the tumultuous years of the Civil War on nearly a daily basis, he had a change of heart. Stanton grew to not only respect Lincoln but to love him. It was said that as Lincoln lay dying in a bedroom across the street from Ford‚Äôs Theater, Edwin Stanton sat in shock in the adjacent parlor‚Ä¶and he wept.

name: Thomas R. Suozzi
content:
On June 19, 1865, a Union General arrived in Galveston, Texas, and issued an order officially freeing all slaves in Texas. This was more than two and a half years after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation.

The struggle for justice has been long, but it will not be denied. This year, as we recognize Juneteenth as a federal holiday, let us recommit ourselves to working together to enact real reforms to create a more equal, fair, and just society.

NYTIMES.COM
So You Want to Learn About Juneteenth?

name: Bobby L. Rush
content:
#Juneteenth is not only a celebration of freedom, but a chance to reflect on HOW America was built and the immense pain and suffering endured by millions of enslaved Black men and women. Acknowledging our nation‚Äôs dark history of slavery ‚Äî and its lingering impacts ‚Äî informs and advances our fight for racial justice today.

The quick action we have seen over the past few days has shown we can move quickly when the political will is there. Now, it‚Äôs time to come together and pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, the John Lewis Voting Rights Act, the Emmett-Till Antilynching Act, and other legislation that will create lasting and meaningful change for Black communities across the country.

name: Bill Huizenga
content:
Democrat Congressman Brian Higgins and I released this joint statement in response to today‚Äôs announcement that border restrictions were once again extended between the US and Canada.

Millions of Americans and Canadians are counting on our governments to work together to reach an agreement that provides a clear roadmap for reopening the border between our two nations. The lack of transparency surrounding these negotiations is a disservice to our constituents and the millions of residents on both sides of the border waiting to see their loved ones, visit their property, and renew business ties. While the arrival of vaccines in record time has been a modern marvel, the inability of the U.S. and Canadian governments to reach an agreement on alleviating border restrictions or aligning additional essential traveler classes is simply unacceptable.

name: Josh Gottheimer
content:
My heart goes out to the President, First Lady, and their whole family. Rest easy, Champ.

President Joe Biden
June 19 at 11:31 AM ¬∑

Our hearts are heavy today as we let you all know that our beloved German Shepherd, Champ, passed away peacefully at home. He was our constant, cherished companion during the last 13 years and was adored by the entire Biden family. Even as Champ‚Äôs strength waned in his last months, when we came into a room, he would immediately pull himself up, his tail always wagging, and nuzzle us for an ear scratch or a belly rub. Wherever we were, he wanted to be, and everything was instantly better when he was next to us. He loved nothing more than curling up at our feet in front of a fire at the end of the day, joining us as a comforting presence in meetings, or sunning himself in the White House garden. In his younger days, he was happiest chasing golf balls on the front lawn of the Naval Observatory or racing to catch our grandchildren as they ran around our backyard in Delaware. In our most joyful moments and in our most grief-stricken days, he was there with us, sensitive to our every unspoken feeling and emotion. We love our sweet, good boy and will miss him always.
text: heart goes president first lady whole family rest easy champpresident joe bidenjune hearts heavy today let know beloved german shepherd champ passed away peacefully home constant cherished companion last years adored entire biden family even champs strength waned last months came room would immediately pull tail always wagging nuzzle us ear scratch belly rub wherever wanted everything instantly better next us loved nothing curling feet front fire end day joining us comforting presence meetings sunning white house garden younger days happiest chasing golf balls front lawn naval observatory racing catch grandchildren ran around backyard delaware joyful moments griefstricken days us sensitive every unspoken feeling emotion love sweet good boy miss always

name: Tom Cole
content: On Juneteenth, we pause to remember a monumental moment in American history more than 150 years ago, and we celebrate its establishment as our newest national holiday. As we reflect on the rightful end of slavery in our country and the emancipation of African Americans held in bondage, we reaffirm our nation‚Äôs founding ideals of liberty and justice for all. Indeed, we should draw strength from Juneteenth‚Äôs role in liberating our history and further refining and defining what our great union was designed to represent for all ‚Äì regardless of color or creed.

name: Garret Graves
content:
In case you missed it - We have an update on the efforts to repeal the Windfall Elimination Penalty (WEP) and the Government Pension Offset (GPO) ‚Äì two problems that I‚Äôm deeply involved in working to solve.

Want to stay in the loop on future WEP/GPO updates?

Visit garretgraves.house.gov/wepgpo and sign up, or click on the link and subscribe.

Please share this post with friends and family in the community experiencing similar issues.

What's the latest?

Right now, the Social Security Fairness Act currently has 167 bipartisan cosponsors. I will continue working with members of both political parties so that we can reach 290 cosponsors. We're not stopping until leadership of the U.S. House brings the bill to the floor for a vote.

I have co-authored this legislation to fix this penalty, which punishes tens of thousands of Louisiana public servants. We continue pushing for the House to vote on this legislation and if it passes, Louisiana's dedicated public servants and their spouses or survivors will receive the full retirement benefits they deserve, including those who have already retired. It remains among my greatest priorities in Congress.

Public servants in Louisiana (teachers, firefighters, etc.) are some of the most impacted victims of the infamous WEP and GPO ‚Äì a flawed federal law that can result in massive cuts in their Social Security retirement.

I am proud to lead a bipartisan coalition of members, advocates, and retirees that are fighting in Congress to fix this broken policy because it punishes our public servants for unfounded reasons.

name: John Katko
content:
This week, I voted in support of a bipartisan bill that is now law to make Juneteenth a federal holiday. Juneteenth commemorates June 19th 1865, when Union soldiers brought the news of freedom to enslaved African Americans in Texas, over two years after the Emancipation Proclamation was signed in 1863. Today Juneteenth is meant to celebrate the freedom this day represents and to call attention to the progress our country still needs to make to eliminate racism and become a more fair and just nation.

name: J. Hill
content:
I‚Äôm concerned that federal agencies ceased their operations and closed their doors today without prior notice to constituents. Agencies such as the VA, USCIS, and Dept. of State carry out crucial and needed services for Arkansans, and closing without giving proper notification has caused further difficulty and delays to hard working Arkansans.

Those in need of VA services or those who need to get in touch regarding their benefits were not able to do so. Additionally, the constituents who have been patiently waiting for their naturalization ceremonies or court hearings or emergency passport appointments were left without any prior notice of closures, and may now have to wait weeks.

If you need assistance with the VA regarding benefits or are traveling soon and need a passport, reach out to my office at 501-324-5941

name: Judy Chu
content: It took 2.5 years for enslaved people in Texas to learn they'd been freed by the Emancipation Proclamation. But it's taken even longer for many Americans to learn about this historic day. That's why I voted to make #Juneteenth a Federal holiday. By making #Juneteenth a Federal holiday, we voted to ensure more Americans know this history. Because, just as we celebrate America‚Äôs freedom from the tyranny of a king, so must we celebrate Black Americans‚Äô freedom from the tyranny of slavery as an equally important step in the creation of the world‚Äôs greatest democracy.

name: Ed Perlmutter
content:
Today marks the first year in which the United States will commemorate June 19th as a federal holiday. On this day, 156 years ago, Union troops arrived in Galveston, Texas to notify the last remaining enslaved Americans that the Civil War was over and they were free.

Although the United States identifies as the land of the free, for over 400 years it was far from that for too many. We need to teach and understand the significance and history of Juneteenth, and our schools need to accurately incorporate this history into curriculums for a deeper understanding of our nation‚Äôs history.

I‚Äôm glad to see we are recognizing the day as a federal holiday but we still have a lot of work to do to in order to achieve true justice and equality for all Americans, such as protecting the right to vote. This is an important time in our history and I encourage all of us to continue to learn, listen and to advocate for equality and a brighter future for all Americans. #Juneteenth

name: John R. Moolenaar
content:
On this day in 1865, Union General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas and announced the end of slavery in the state in accordance with Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation. Celebrated in many parts of the United States for more than 150 years, Juneteenth became our nation's newest federal holiday this week. You can learn more about this celebration of freedom by clicking the link below from the Library of Congress.

name: John R. Curtis
content:
Nothing is all good or all bad, and this is especially true with the Affordable Care Act (ACA). This week's ruling on the Affordable Care Act highlights the need for us to find bipartisan solutions to improve the quality of American health care, especially in light of premium increases and quality of care decline that was caused by the one-sized-fits-all nature of the Affordable Care Act.

To that end, I have introduced several bipartisan bills that empower patients by giving them more choice over their health care in addition to increasing access to care through telehealth and by expanding tax-advantaged health-savings accounts. I look forward to continuing to be a leader on these important issues and working across the aisle to find common-sense solutions for hard-working Americans.

NPR.ORG
Obamacare Wins For The 3rd Time At The Supreme Court

name: Rick Larsen
content:
Today marks the first time Juneteenth is observed as a legal federal holiday, a small step toward recognizing the important role Black Americans have played in the history of our country and the work that remains to address systemic racism in the United States.

Take advantage of the day: attend live events in the Second District or virtual events like ones hosted by the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture. Take time to read about the history and significance of June 19, 1865, and share what you have learned with family and friends.

I also want to acknowledge the hard work of leaders like Washington Reps. Melanie Morgan and John Lovick, organizations like NAACP Snohomish County and community members who led the charge to make Juneteenth a legal state holiday in Washington.
text: today marks first time juneteenth observed legal federal holiday small step toward recognizing important role black americans played history country work remains address systemic racism united statestake advantage day attend live events second district virtual events like ones hosted smithsonian national museum african american history culture take time read history significance june share learned family friendsi also want acknowledge hard work leaders like washington reps melanie morgan john lovick organizations like naacp snohomish county community members led charge make juneteenth legal state holiday washington

name: Doris O. Matsui
content:
#Juneteenth is a time to reflect on where we have been and celebrate how far we have come, but also to focus on how much work we still have to do towards building a more inclusive, equitable future for all people in our country.

Over the past year, our nation has faced a reckoning on racism and the structural injustices that still permeate our society.

We must continue to find ways to right our historical wrongs, lift our voices, and share our stories. As part of our healing, we must continue to come together and fight for a more perfect union and a more equitable tomorrow.

This week, the House and the Senate passed legislation making Juneteenth a federal holiday, and President Biden signed it into law. This is a historic moment for America, and we will continue to move forward together.

#Juneteenth2021

https://matsui.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=2133

name: Adam Smith
content:
On June 19, 1865, Major General Gordon Granger led Union soldiers led into Galveston, Texas with news that the Civil War had ended and that the people held in slavery there were free ‚Äì but it was two and a half years after President Lincoln‚Äôs Emancipation Proclamation legally abolishing slavery in the United States.

156 years later, Congress has recognized the long-standing tradition among Black Americans to memorialize the end of slavery by establishing Juneteenth National Independence Day as a federal holiday. This day marks one of the most important moments in our country's history. It was the starting point on a path to equal justice under the law and equitable opportunity for all in America, that continues even today.

This Juneteenth arrives at a time when the national conversation on police brutality, criminal justice, health care and social services access, infrastructure investment, and good governance acknowledges the reality of systemic racism, which disproportionately places the heaviest burdens and the harshest penalties on Black people. Change is long overdue. Commemoration alone is not enough to rid the country of the existing legacies of slavery especially in light of unprecedented attacks on the right to vote and recognition of our country‚Äôs history of slavery in state legislatures across the country.

I am proud and grateful to join in celebrating Juneteenth with my friend LaNesha DeBardelaben, the Northwest African American Museum, Rec'N The Streets, and many others on a day that symbolizes the beginning of freedom for so many Black Americans. I recommit to the work still ahead of us ‚Äì I remain committed to doing everything in my power to fight hate and racism and I will not stop until every American has equal opportunities to succeed.

name: Jerry McNerney
content: Two and a half years after the Emancipation Proclamation, Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, TX and announced the end of the Civil War and slavery in the United States. The day was June 19th, 1865. Juneteenth, or Black Independence Day, marks the end of a dark stain on our nation‚Äôs history and a major step on our continuing and unfinished path to build a more perfect union. This past week, my colleagues and I passed legislation to make this important day a federal holiday, which President Biden signed into law. Commemorating this day is a reminder of how far we have come as a country, and a rallying call to continue to work toward equality for all.

name: Steve Chabot
content:
This week, Congress passed, and President Biden signed into law, legislation making Juneteenth (a day originally set aside to celebrate the end of slavery in the Confederacy) a federal holiday.

Why June 19th? Because on June 19, 1865, Union General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas and informed all enslaved people in Texas that they were now free. Even though the Civil War had been over for more than two months and President Lincoln had signed the Emancipation Proclamation two and a half years earlier, many African Americans remained enslaved until the Union Army arrived to enforce the law. As a result, African Americans in Galveston have celebrated their emancipation on Juneteenth (June 19th) every year.

For more than 150 years that initially local celebration has spread far and wide, and become something of an unofficial national holiday commemorating the end of slavery in the United States. Well, now it‚Äôs official. Juneteenth commemorates an incredibly important milestone in our continuing effort to attain a more perfect union, by celebrating freedom, equality and basic human dignity.
text: week congress passed president biden signed law legislation making juneteenth day originally set aside celebrate end slavery confederacy federal holidaywhy june 19th june union general gordon granger arrived galveston texas informed enslaved people texas free even though civil war two months president lincoln signed emancipation proclamation two half years earlier many african americans remained enslaved union army arrived enforce law result african americans galveston celebrated emancipation juneteenth june 19th every yearfor years initially local celebration spread far wide become something unofficial national holiday commemorating end slavery united states well official juneteenth commemorates incredibly important milestone continuing effort attain perfect union celebrating freedom equality basic human dignity

content:
The hardworking men and women at the 88th Air Base Wing deserve adequate facilities, and that includes a safe, and suitable child center for the hundreds of children of base employees. Yet the current child center is a failing, off-base facility with insufficient capacity.

That is why I requested $24 million to fund the construction of a new Child Development Center. This new facility would have the capacity for more than 300 children and include force protection features, and necessary spaces including classroom and play areas.

This is a desperately needed facility for Wright-Patt that I will work diligently to secure.

name: John R. Carter
content:
On June 19, 1865, news from Union troops finally arrived in Galveston, Texas that more than 250,000 enslaved people were free by executive decree.

On Thursday, I was proud to join 414 of my colleagues in making this day, known as Juneteenth, a federal holiday. May we never forget our history and always strive to be a more perfect union where all men are created equally and endowed by their Creator with the inalienable rights of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.
text: june news union troops finally arrived galveston texas enslaved people free executive decreeon thursday proud join colleagues making day known juneteenth federal holiday may never forget history always strive perfect union men created equally endowed creator inalienable rights life liberty pursuit happiness

name: Jerry McNerney
content:
As we celebrate Fathers‚Äô Day today, I‚Äôm thinking a lot about my own father, John Edward McNerney ‚Äì a man who cared a great deal about his family and tried to always be there for us. He was a pillar in our community, setting an example of a virtuous life with his strong convictions. Before volunteering in the U.S. Army during WW2, he was a proud engineer and a union man in San Francisco in the 1930‚Äôs. He later retired from the reÔøºserves as a Colonel.

I wasn‚Äôt always close to my father, and we certainly had our share of disagreements, but I always respected him as my father and as a human, who ‚Äì like all of us ‚Äì had his strengths and weaknesses.

They say that the apple doesn‚Äôt falls far from the tree, and I see my father in myself more and more as I enter my seventh decade. Like many children, I‚Äôve always wanted to make my father proud. I hope that I have lived up to his standards and his expectations of me because I truly believe the guiding principles he lived by make for a good person in any society.

Some of us are celebrating today with loved ones who are still with us. Some of us, like me, are missing the ones we‚Äôve lost. But I hope you all take a moment to reflect upon and thank the fathers, grandfathers and other father-figures in your life. And to those who have had the great opportunity to play one of those roles to someone important to you, Happy Father‚Äôs Day.
text: celebrate fathers day today im thinking lot father john edward mcnerney man cared great deal family tried always us pillar community setting example virtuous life strong convictions volunteering us army ww2 proud engineer union man san francisco 1930s later retired reserves coloneli wasnt always close father certainly share disagreements always respected father human like us strengths weaknessesthey say apple doesnt falls far tree see father enter seventh decade like many children ive always wanted make father proud hope lived standards expectations truly believe guiding principles lived make good person societysome us celebrating today loved ones still us us like missing ones weve lost hope take moment reflect upon thank fathers grandfathers fatherfigures life great opportunity play one roles someone important happy fathers day

name: Tom Cole
content:
In case you missed it earlier this week, I was delighted to hear that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced the selection of the Fourth Congressional District's own University of Oklahoma to host NOAA‚Äôs Cooperative Institute for Severe and High-Impact Weather Research and Operations!

Already home to the National Weather Center, OU is certainly well positioned to host this research institute to improve the understanding of severe and high-impact weather. Indeed, the results of research efforts could pave the way for producing more accurate forecasts and warnings in the future, which would not only benefit Oklahomans ‚Äì who know to expect severe weather ‚Äì but all Americans in response to weather patterns. Indeed, with better forecasts and warnings, we can be better prepared for the worst and ultimately save lives and protect property. I am proud to congratulate OU on its selection for this worthwhile research effort.

#FourthDistrictFriday

OKLAHOMAN.COM
Producing better forecasts and saving lives: OU lands $208 million to continue tornado research

name: Debbie Wasserman Schultz
content:
Tomorrow will be the first time in American history that we as a nation will observe Juneteenth as a federal holiday. Join the Congressional Caucus on Black-Jewish Relations for a live virtual roundtable to celebrate!

Rep. Brenda Lawrence was live.
June 18 at 11:06 AM ¬∑

Juneteenth marks an historic day in which the people of Galveston, Texas were informed of the emancipation of enslaved African Americans in the United States. On Friday, June 18, 2021 from 11:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 PM, U.S. Representative Brenda L. Lawrence (MI-14), U.S. Representative Lee Zeldin, and U.S. Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz will host a virtual roundtable to discuss political and social issues following the 1865 notification of the emancipation of slavery, and how we can use our diversity of voices through allyship today and tomorrow to lift up one another. Rep. Lawrence will be joined by distinguished panelists Joi Chaney, Dov Wilker, and Kinshasha Holman Conwill. The virtual roundtable will be hosted virtually via Zoom webinar, and members of the press will be allowed to ask questions. A recording of the virtual roundtable will be provided to participating press after the event.

The Congressional Caucus on Black-Jewish Relations aims to bring together politicians from both communities, and both sides of the aisle, to learn from each other and advocate for joint concerns. The Caucus is dedicated to raising awareness of each community‚Äôs sensitivities and needs, in Congress and around the country. It also provides resources to members of Congress to empower them to bring African American and Jewish communities together, combating stereotypes and hate and showcasing commonalities.
text: tomorrow first time american history nation observe juneteenth federal holiday join congressional caucus blackjewish relations live virtual roundtable celebraterep brenda lawrence livejune juneteenth marks historic day people galveston texas informed emancipation enslaved african americans united states friday june pm us representative brenda l lawrence mi14 us representative lee zeldin us representative debbie wasserman schultz host virtual roundtable discuss political social issues following notification emancipation slavery use diversity voices allyship today tomorrow lift one another rep lawrence joined distinguished panelists joi chaney dov wilker kinshasha holman conwill virtual roundtable hosted virtually via zoom webinar members press allowed ask questions recording virtual roundtable provided participating press eventthe congressional caucus blackjewish relations aims bring together politicians communities sides aisle learn advocate joint concerns caucus dedicated raising awareness communitys sensitivities needs congress around country also provides resources members congress empower bring african american jewish communities together combating stereotypes hate showcasing commonalities

Russ is a dear friend and as he begins this new fight I know he‚Äôll do so with the same determination that he fights for Idahoans everyday in our nation‚Äôs capital. I‚Äôd ask that you join Kathy and I as we pray for his health and give him and his family the privacy they deserve because Idaho needs Russ.

Rep. Russ Fulcher
June 17 at 8:17 PM ¬∑

A personal note to my friends and neighbors:

I frequently reach out to you to communicate politically themed messages or request your counsel regarding the same. But today‚Äôs message is for a different purpose‚Ä¶ to relay some personal information.

No one likes to hear the ‚ÄúC‚Äù word, especially when having a discussion with their physician, but as many of you have previously experienced‚Ä¶ sometimes it happens. I recently learned that there is cancer in a portion of my renal system.
The good news is: My case is treatable, and I anticipate a full recovery. Throughout the treatment process I will be diligent in continuing my congressional duties.

As a Christian, I believe things happen for a reason. This is a time for me to learn and grow from what many of you already have personal appreciation for. By the time it‚Äôs over I will be better educated, have more compassion for those with similar experiences, have increased appreciation for our healthcare system, and be a better person!

As always, should you need assistance working through federal issues or have policy concerns, do not hesitate to contact one of my offices. Thank you for your understanding, and your prayers!

name: Brenda L. Lawrence
content:
Juneteenth marks an historic day in which the people of Galveston, Texas were informed of the emancipation of enslaved African Americans in the United States. On Friday, June 18, 2021 from 11:00 AM ‚Äì 12:00 PM, U.S. Representative Brenda L. Lawrence (MI-14), U.S. Representative Lee Zeldin, and U.S. Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz will host a virtual roundtable to discuss political and social issues following the 1865 notification of the emancipation of slavery, and how we can use our diversity of voices through allyship today and tomorrow to lift up one another. Rep. Lawrence will be joined by distinguished panelists Joi Chaney, Dov Wilker, and Kinshasha Holman Conwill. The virtual roundtable will be hosted virtually via Zoom webinar, and members of the press will be allowed to ask questions. A recording of the virtual roundtable will be provided to participating press after the event.

The Congressional Caucus on Black-Jewish Relations aims to bring together politicians from both communities, and both sides of the aisle, to learn from each other and advocate for joint concerns. The Caucus is dedicated to raising awareness of each community‚Äôs sensitivities and needs, in Congress and around the country. It also provides resources to members of Congress to empower them to bring African American and Jewish communities together, combating stereotypes and hate and showcasing commonalities.

name: Jeff Fortenberry
content:
FORT REPORT: FIXING A HOLE

This Fort Report is far away from your concerns in Nebraska, but it‚Äôs important. When I was a college student, I took part in an exchange program in Egypt. I lived among the poor, with farmers, with the wealthy, with elected officials. I even sipped tea with the Bedouins in the Sinai Desert.

Fast forward forty years. As a Member of Congress on the Appropriations Subcommittee with oversight responsibility for the State Department and Foreign Operations, I am constantly considering matters of Middle East policy. On a fairly recent return trip to Egypt, I had a lengthy, encouraging visit with President Sisi, as well as meaningful dialogue with Egypt‚Äôs ancient Christian community and the Grand Imam of al-Azhar mosque. I took a side trip to the old marketplace where I spent time decades before. While walking along one of its narrow corridors, I stepped in a hole. I looked down and said to my host, "I think I stepped in that hole forty years ago." We laughed. In the Middle East, some holes are hard to fix.

In neighboring Israel, we recently watched another traumatic flareup of hostilities between Israelis and Palestinians. For years, politicians have touted "the road map for peace." But, as I have often said, every road needs a foundation.

Some time ago, a proposed a new idea called the Middle East Partnership for Peace Act to reestablish the preconditions of trust as a foundation for lasting peace. I am pleased to report that due to a concerted leadership push by former Appropriations Chairwoman Nita Lowey of New York, the Nita Lowey Middle East Partnership for Peace Act (MEPPA) is now law.

Given the recent Egypt-orchestrated ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinians, the pressing need for transformative ideas for peacebuilding, and a shifting political environment, implementation of MEPPA is now a ripe policy consideration. MEPPA does two things: it builds trust through traditional people-to-people exchanges; it creatively deploys the U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) to jumpstart hugely beneficial private equity projects.

The business projects envisioned by MEPPA will have Israeli and Palestinian partners, with a particular focus on sustainable agriculture. The idea is that whether politics lurches left, lurches right, or something blows up, these profitable, mutually enriching ventures will be hard to unwind. The bill also has embedded safeguards to ensure that funds flow directly to these projects, not through governments, and not towards nefarious actors who could use the money to perpetuate violence.

From an initial concept over six years ago, we are now building out a MEPPA board, as we work to make an abstract policy idea real for people on the ground. In my recent exchanges with U.S. Secretary of State Blinken and U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Administrator Power, there was strong agreement about the importance of this new tool.

I realize that your personal considerations are very far from these foreign policy dynamics. But this work for peace is ultimately about creating stability to protect us all. More people lost their lives to war in the 20th century than in all other wars in human history. While we consider ourselves modern and advanced, violence and the means of escalating violence are only increasing.

Tools like MEPPA, rooted in human relationship, understanding, respect, prosperity, and trust, offer another way‚Äì‚Äìto build the foundation of the roadmap for peace. Maybe that hole I stepped in can finally get fixed too.

https://fortenberry.house.gov/news/fort-report/fort-report-fixing-hole

FORTENBERRY.HOUSE.GOV
Fort Report: Fixing a Hole

name: John R. Carter
content:
Juvenile-on-juvenile crime on military installations has often gone undealt with because of a jurisdictional blackhole between federal, state, and local law enforcement. This has left victims without justice and perpetrators without consequences. For the last two Congresses, I have introduced legislation to develop a standard on military installations that will turn jurisdiction over to local law enforcement and state prosecutors, while providing support for victims and their families. As a result of my legislation, the Army has adopted a new policy that will require them to contact law enforcement within 24 hours of incident to hand over jurisdiction and establish support teams for victims on every Army base.

CARTER.HOUSE.GOV
Carter's Language Prompts Army to Implement New Policy Regarding Juvenile-on-Juvenile Sexual Crimes

I applaud the hard work of Governor Murphy, State Health Commissioner Perischilli, and all those who have worked tirelessly over the past months to get New Jerseyans vaccinated.

Governor Murphy set a deadline to fully vaccinate 4.7 million adult residents by June 30th so that 70% of our adult population would be protected from COVID-19.

This goal was achieved well ahead of schedule and is a testament not only to Governor Murphy and those who worked on distributing vaccines but also the people of New Jersey, who have shown a commitment to the public health of their communities throughout the pandemic.

name: Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan
content:
As the cost of college continues to rise, the amount of federal aid available to students in need has not kept up. That is why I joined House and Senate Democrats to introduce the Pell Grant Preservation and Expansion Act on Wednesday. The bill indexes the Pell grant to inflation and sets a five-year plan to reach a $13,000 maximum award in 2027-28, which is double the 2021-22 limit of $6,495. The bill also makes Pell Grant funding fully mandatory to protect it from funding shortfalls. About 1,000 Northern Marianas College students each year pay for their tuition and other expenses with Pell grants.

Read more on the bill here:
https://edlabor.house.gov/media/press-releases/pocan-scott-hirono-murray-introduce-bill-to-double-pell-grant-make-college-more-affordable

EDLABOR.HOUSE.GOV
Pocan, Scott, Hirono, Murray Introduce Bill to Double Pell Grant, Make College More Affordable | House Committee on Education and Labor
text: cost college continues rise amount federal aid available students need kept joined house senate democrats introduce pell grant preservation expansion act wednesday bill indexes pell grant inflation sets fiveyear plan reach maximum award double limit bill also makes pell grant funding fully mandatory protect funding shortfalls northern marianas college students year pay tuition expenses pell grantsread bill hereedlaborhousegovpocan scott hirono murray introduce bill double pell grant make college affordable house committee education labor

name: Adam Smith
content: This week is Black Family Cancer Awareness Week. Black Americans have the highest death rate of any racial group in the U.S. for all cancers combined. Black men have the highest death rate for prostate cancer of any racial/ethnic group in the U.S.‚Äîmore than 2x that of white Americans. Black women have lower incidence rates of breast cancer than white Americans but are more likely to die of the disease. It‚Äôs time to close these gaps. To learn more and reduce your risk of cancer, visit: preventcancer.org/sevensteps #CongressionalFamilies #BlackFamCan
